question_name: Which condition is characterized by the appearance of silvery scales on the skin?
question_description: Identify the dermatological condition that presents with silvery scales.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis is characterized by silvery scales.

options.name: Eczema
options.description: Eczema typically presents with red, itchy patches.

options.name: Rosacea
options.description: Rosacea often causes redness and visible blood vessels.

options.name: Acne
options.description: Acne involves pimples, blackheads, and whiteheads.

question_name: What is the primary cause of acne?
question_description: Identify the main factor contributing to the development of acne.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Fungal Infection
options.description: Acne is not caused by fungal infections.

options.name: Viral Infection
options.description: Acne is not caused by viral infections.

options.name: Bacterial Infection
options.description: Acne is primarily caused by bacterial infection of hair follicles.

options.name: Parasitic Infection
options.description: Acne is not caused by parasitic infections.

question_name: What is the most common cause of contact dermatitis?
question_description: Identify the leading cause of contact dermatitis.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Exposure to sunlight
options.description: Sunlight exposure typically causes sunburn, not contact dermatitis.

options.name: Allergic reaction to substances
options.description: Allergic reactions to substances like poison ivy or certain metals are the most common causes of contact dermatitis.

options.name: Bacterial infection
options.description: Bacterial infections are not a common cause of contact dermatitis.

options.name: Viral infection
options.description: Viral infections are not a common cause of contact dermatitis.

question_name: What skin condition is commonly known as atopic dermatitis?
question_description: Identify the skin condition also referred to as atopic dermatitis.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis is a separate condition with distinct features.

options.name: Eczema
options.description: Atopic dermatitis is commonly known as eczema.

options.name: Rosacea
options.description: Rosacea is not known as atopic dermatitis.

options.name: Acne
options.description: Acne is not known as atopic dermatitis.

question_name: Which vitamin deficiency can lead to the development of scaly skin?
question_description: Identify the vitamin deficiency that can cause scaly skin.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Vitamin A
options.description: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to xerosis, which manifests as dry, scaly skin.

options.name: Vitamin C
options.description: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, which affects gums and skin, but not primarily scaly skin.

options.name: Vitamin D
options.description: Vitamin D deficiency leads to bone issues rather than scaly skin.

options.name: Vitamin B12
options.description: Vitamin B12 deficiency typically affects the nervous system rather than causing scaly skin.

question_name: What is the characteristic finding in lichen planus?
question_description: Identify the primary clinical feature of lichen planus.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Wickham striae
options.description: Wickham striae are fine white lines on the surface of lichen planus lesions.

options.name: Butterfly rash
options.description: Butterfly rash is characteristic of lupus erythematosus.

options.name: Herald patch
options.description: Herald patch is a feature of pityriasis rosea.

options.name: Koebner phenomenon
options.description: Koebner phenomenon can occur in lichen planus but is not its primary feature.

question_name: Which condition is characterized by target lesions?
question_description: Identify the dermatological condition associated with target lesions.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Erythema multiforme
options.description: Erythema multiforme is characterized by target lesions.

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis does not typically present with target lesions.

options.name: Lichen planus
options.description: Lichen planus presents with flat-topped, purple papules.

options.name: Rosacea
options.description: Rosacea is characterized by facial redness and pimples.

question_name: What is the hallmark feature of pemphigus vulgaris?
question_description: Identify the primary characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Acantholysis
options.description: Acantholysis, or loss of keratinocyte adhesion, is the hallmark of pemphigus vulgaris.

options.name: Subepidermal blistering
options.description: Subepidermal blistering is seen in bullous pemphigoid, not pemphigus vulgaris.

options.name: Hyperkeratosis
options.description: Hyperkeratosis is a feature of chronic eczema and psoriasis.

options.name: Granuloma formation
options.description: Granuloma formation is seen in conditions like sarcoidosis.

question_name: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in allergic contact dermatitis?
question_description: Identify the type of hypersensitivity reaction responsible for allergic contact dermatitis.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Type I
options.description: Type I hypersensitivity is immediate and includes conditions like anaphylaxis.

options.name: Type II
options.description: Type II hypersensitivity involves cytotoxic reactions, such as hemolytic anemia.

options.name: Type III
options.description: Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complexes, seen in conditions like lupus.

options.name: Type IV
options.description: Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed reaction, as seen in allergic contact dermatitis.

question_name: What is the primary treatment for scabies?
question_description: Identify the most common treatment used for scabies.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Topical steroids
options.description: Topical steroids are not used to treat scabies.

options.name: Antifungal creams
options.description: Antifungal creams are not effective against scabies mites.

options.name: Permethrin cream
options.description: Permethrin cream is the first-line treatment for scabies.

options.name: Oral antibiotics
options.description: Oral antibiotics are not used to treat scabies.

question_name: Which dermatological condition presents with a 'herald patch'?
question_description: Identify the condition characterized by the presence of a herald patch.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Pityriasis rosea
options.description: Pityriasis rosea typically begins with a herald patch followed by a generalized rash.

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis does not typically begin with a herald patch.

options.name: Lichen planus
options.description: Lichen planus does not present with a herald patch.

options.name: Erythema multiforme
options.description: Erythema multiforme is characterized by target lesions, not a herald patch.

question_name: Which skin infection is caused by group A Streptococcus?
question_description: Identify the skin infection commonly caused by group A Streptococcus.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Impetigo
options.description: Impetigo is commonly caused by group A Streptococcus and presents with honey-colored crusts.

options.name: Tinea corporis
options.description: Tinea corporis is a fungal infection, not caused by bacteria.

options.name: Herpes simplex
options.description: Herpes simplex is a viral infection, not caused by bacteria.

options.name: Scabies
options.description: Scabies is caused by mites, not bacteria.

question_name: Which vitamin deficiency can lead to the development of pellagra?
question_description: Identify the vitamin deficiency that causes pellagra.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Vitamin A
options.description: Vitamin A deficiency leads to night blindness and xerosis.

options.name: Vitamin C
options.description: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy.

options.name: Niacin (Vitamin B3)
options.description: Niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

options.name: Vitamin D
options.description: Vitamin D deficiency leads to rickets and osteomalacia.

question_name: Which dermatological condition is associated with gluten sensitivity?
question_description: Identify the condition that is often seen in patients with gluten sensitivity.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis is not specifically associated with gluten sensitivity.

options.name: Dermatitis herpetiformis
options.description: Dermatitis herpetiformis is strongly associated with gluten sensitivity and celiac disease.

options.name: Lichen planus
options.description: Lichen planus is not specifically associated with gluten sensitivity.

options.name: Rosacea
options.description: Rosacea is not specifically associated with gluten sensitivity.

question_name: Which condition is characterized by a 'sandpaper' texture of the skin?
question_description: Identify the condition that presents with a rough, sandpaper-like texture on the skin.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Actinic keratosis
options.description: Actinic keratosis presents with rough, sandpaper-like lesions due to sun damage.

options.name: Seborrheic dermatitis
options.description: Seborrheic dermatitis presents with greasy, flaky scales, not a sandpaper texture.

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis presents with thick, silvery scales, not a sandpaper texture.

options.name: Tinea versicolor
options.description: Tinea versicolor presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches, not a sandpaper texture.

question_name: What is the primary cause of erythroderma in adults?
question_description: Identify the most common cause of erythroderma in adult patients.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis is the most common cause of erythroderma in adults.

options.name: Eczema
options.description: Eczema can cause erythroderma, but it is not the most common cause.

options.name: Drug reaction
options.description: Drug reactions can lead to erythroderma but are less common than psoriasis.

options.name: Lymphoma
options.description: Lymphoma can cause erythroderma but is less common compared to psoriasis.

question_name: Which genetic disorder is characterized by the presence of multiple basal cell carcinomas?
question_description: Identify the genetic disorder associated with multiple basal cell carcinomas.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Gorlin syndrome
options.description: Gorlin syndrome, or basal cell nevus syndrome, is characterized by multiple basal cell carcinomas.

options.name: Gardner syndrome
options.description: Gardner syndrome is associated with colonic polyps and osteomas, not basal cell carcinomas.

options.name: Neurofibromatosis
options.description: Neurofibromatosis is associated with neurofibromas, not basal cell carcinomas.

options.name: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
options.description: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with gastrointestinal polyps and mucocutaneous pigmentation, not basal cell carcinomas.

question_name: Which autoimmune blistering disorder is characterized by IgG antibodies against desmoglein?
question_description: Identify the autoimmune blistering disorder with IgG antibodies against desmoglein.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Pemphigus vulgaris
options.description: Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by IgG antibodies against desmoglein, leading to intraepidermal blistering.

options.name: Bullous pemphigoid
options.description: Bullous pemphigoid is associated with antibodies against hemidesmosomes, not desmoglein.

options.name: Dermatitis herpetiformis
options.description: Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase.

options.name: Epidermolysis bullosa
options.description: Epidermolysis bullosa is a genetic disorder, not an autoimmune condition with IgG antibodies against desmoglein.

question_name: What is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma?
question_description: Identify the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Mycosis fungoides
options.description: Mycosis fungoides is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.

options.name: Sezary syndrome
options.description: Sezary syndrome is a leukemic variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma but is less common than mycosis fungoides.

options.name: Primary cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma
options.description: Primary cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma but less common than mycosis fungoides.

options.name: Lymphomatoid papulosis
options.description: Lymphomatoid papulosis is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma but is considered less common and less aggressive.

question_name: Which dermatologic condition is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy?
question_description: Identify the skin condition linked with gluten-sensitive enteropathy.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Dermatitis herpetiformis
options.description: Dermatitis herpetiformis is strongly associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease).

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis is not specifically associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

options.name: Lichen planus
options.description: Lichen planus is not specifically associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

options.name: Vitiligo
options.description: Vitiligo is an autoimmune condition but not specifically associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

question_name: What is the treatment of choice for localized cutaneous leishmaniasis?
question_description: Identify the preferred treatment for localized cutaneous leishmaniasis.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Pentavalent antimonials
options.description: Pentavalent antimonials are the treatment of choice for localized cutaneous leishmaniasis.

options.name: Oral itraconazole
options.description: Oral itraconazole is used for fungal infections, not typically for leishmaniasis.

options.name: Topical steroids
options.description: Topical steroids are not used to treat cutaneous leishmaniasis.

options.name: Oral acyclovir
options.description: Oral acyclovir is used for viral infections, not for leishmaniasis.

question_name: What is the most common cause of erythema nodosum?
question_description: Identify the most common cause of erythema nodosum.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Streptococcal infection
options.description: Streptococcal infections are the most common cause of erythema nodosum.

options.name: Tuberculosis
options.description: Tuberculosis can cause erythema nodosum but is less common than streptococcal infections.

options.name: Sarcoidosis
options.description: Sarcoidosis can cause erythema nodosum but is less common than streptococcal infections.

options.name: Inflammatory bowel disease
options.description: Inflammatory bowel disease can cause erythema nodosum but is less common than streptococcal infections.

question_name: Which condition is associated with the Auspitz sign?
question_description: Identify the dermatologic condition associated with the Auspitz sign.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: The Auspitz sign, where bleeding points appear when scales are removed, is characteristic of psoriasis.

options.name: Lichen planus
options.description: Lichen planus is not associated with the Auspitz sign.

options.name: Pityriasis rosea
options.description: Pityriasis rosea is not associated with the Auspitz sign.

options.name: Seborrheic dermatitis
options.description: Seborrheic dermatitis is not associated with the Auspitz sign.

question_name: Which infection is known to cause Kaposi's sarcoma?
question_description: Identify the infectious agent associated with Kaposi's sarcoma.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)
options.description: Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is the causative agent of Kaposi's sarcoma.

options.name: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)
options.description: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is associated with Burkitt's lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma, not Kaposi's sarcoma.

options.name: Human papillomavirus (HPV)
options.description: Human papillomavirus (HPV) is associated with cervical cancer and warts, not Kaposi's sarcoma.

options.name: Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
options.description: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is associated with various infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, but not specifically with Kaposi's sarcoma.

question_name: What is the hallmark of lichen sclerosus?
question_description: Identify the characteristic feature of lichen sclerosus.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: White, atrophic patches
options.description: Lichen sclerosus is characterized by white, atrophic patches on the skin, often in the genital area.

options.name: Hyperpigmented macules
options.description: Hyperpigmented macules are not characteristic of lichen sclerosus.

options.name: Bullous eruptions
options.description: Bullous eruptions are not characteristic of lichen sclerosus.

options.name: Erythematous plaques
options.description: Erythematous plaques are not characteristic of lichen sclerosus.

question_name: Which genetic mutation is most commonly associated with Hailey-Hailey disease?
question_description: Identify the genetic mutation commonly linked to Hailey-Hailey disease.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: ATP2C1
options.description: Hailey-Hailey disease is caused by mutations in the ATP2C1 gene.

options.name: KRT1
options.description: Mutations in KRT1 are associated with epidermolytic hyperkeratosis, not Hailey-Hailey disease.

options.name: COL7A1
options.description: Mutations in COL7A1 are associated with dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa.

options.name: GJB2
options.description: Mutations in GJB2 are associated with certain forms of deafness, not Hailey-Hailey disease.

question_name: Which type of lupus erythematosus is characterized by the presence of chilblains?
question_description: Identify the type of lupus erythematosus that presents with chilblains.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Chilblain lupus erythematosus
options.description: Chilblain lupus erythematosus presents with painful red or purplish lesions on the fingers, toes, and other extremities.

options.name: Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus
options.description: Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus typically presents with photosensitive annular or psoriasiform lesions.

options.name: Discoid lupus erythematosus
options.description: Discoid lupus erythematosus presents with chronic, scarring plaques, typically on the face and scalp.

options.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus
options.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus can affect multiple organs and systems, including the skin, but chilblains are not a characteristic feature.

question_name: Which cutaneous manifestation is most commonly associated with systemic sclerosis?
question_description: Identify the cutaneous manifestation commonly linked to systemic sclerosis.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Sclerodactyly
options.description: Sclerodactyly, or tightening of the skin on the fingers and hands, is a hallmark of systemic sclerosis.

options.name: Gottron's papules
options.description: Gottron's papules are characteristic of dermatomyositis, not systemic sclerosis.

options.name: Erythema nodosum
options.description: Erythema nodosum is associated with a variety of conditions, including infections and inflammatory diseases, but not specifically with systemic sclerosis.

options.name: Acanthosis nigricans
options.description: Acanthosis nigricans is typically associated with insulin resistance and other conditions, not systemic sclerosis.

question_name: Which drug is most likely to induce a lichenoid drug eruption?
question_description: Identify the drug commonly known to cause lichenoid drug eruptions.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Gold salts
options.description: Gold salts, used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, can cause lichenoid drug eruptions.

options.name: Ciprofloxacin
options.description: Ciprofloxacin can cause various cutaneous side effects, but lichenoid drug eruptions are not typical.

options.name: Isotretinoin
options.description: Isotretinoin can cause dryness and other skin changes but not typically lichenoid drug eruptions.

options.name: Aspirin
options.description: Aspirin is not commonly associated with lichenoid drug eruptions.

question_name: What is the primary defect in X-linked ichthyosis?
question_description: Identify the primary defect responsible for X-linked ichthyosis.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Steroid sulfatase deficiency
options.description: X-linked ichthyosis is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme steroid sulfatase.

options.name: Filaggrin mutation
options.description: Filaggrin mutations are associated with ichthyosis vulgaris, not X-linked ichthyosis.

options.name: Keratin 1 mutation
options.description: Keratin 1 mutations are associated with epidermolytic hyperkeratosis.

options.name: Transglutaminase 1 deficiency
options.description: Transglutaminase 1 deficiency is associated with lamellar ichthyosis.

question_name: Which antibody is most specific for systemic lupus erythematosus?
question_description: Identify the antibody most specific for diagnosing systemic lupus erythematosus.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Anti-Smith antibody
options.description: Anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibody is highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus.

options.name: Anti-Ro antibody
options.description: Anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies are associated with both systemic lupus erythematosus and Sjogren's syndrome but are less specific.

options.name: Anti-dsDNA antibody
options.description: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific and correlate with disease activity in systemic lupus erythematosus but are less specific than anti-Sm.

options.name: Anti-centromere antibody
options.description: Anti-centromere antibodies are associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome), not systemic lupus erythematosus.

question_name: Which type of porphyria is most commonly associated with blistering skin lesions?
question_description: Identify the type of porphyria that typically presents with blistering skin lesions.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Porphyria cutanea tarda
options.description: Porphyria cutanea tarda is characterized by blistering lesions on sun-exposed areas.

options.name: Acute intermittent porphyria
options.description: Acute intermittent porphyria typically does not present with cutaneous manifestations.

options.name: Erythropoietic protoporphyria
options.description: Erythropoietic protoporphyria presents with photosensitivity but not typically with blistering.

options.name: Hereditary coproporphyria
options.description: Hereditary coproporphyria can have cutaneous manifestations, but blistering is more characteristic of porphyria cutanea tarda.

question_name: What is the characteristic histological finding in bullous pemphigoid?
question_description: Identify the characteristic histological finding seen in bullous pemphigoid.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Subepidermal blister with eosinophils
options.description: Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by a subepidermal blister with eosinophils on histological examination.

options.name: Acantholysis with intraepidermal blister
options.description: Acantholysis with intraepidermal blister is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris, not bullous pemphigoid.

options.name: Lymphocytic infiltrate in the dermis
options.description: A lymphocytic infiltrate in the dermis is seen in lichen planus, not bullous pemphigoid.

options.name: Epidermal hyperplasia with parakeratosis
options.description: Epidermal hyperplasia with parakeratosis is characteristic of psoriasis, not bullous pemphigoid.

question_name: Which dermatologic condition is characterized by 'oil drop' sign on dermoscopy?
question_description: Identify the dermatologic condition characterized by 'oil drop' sign on dermoscopy.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Seborrheic keratosis
options.description: Seborrheic keratosis is characterized by the 'oil drop' sign on dermoscopy, which corresponds to milia-like cysts within the lesion.

options.name: Dermatofibroma
options.description: Dermatofibroma typically shows a central white scar-like patch on dermoscopy, known as 'central white patch' sign.

options.name: Basal cell carcinoma
options.description: Basal cell carcinoma may show arborizing vessels on dermoscopy, but not specifically the 'oil drop' sign.

options.name: Melanoma
options.description: Melanoma can show irregular pigment network or asymmetric structures on dermoscopy, but not the 'oil drop' sign.

question_name: Which skin condition presents with 'dew drops on a rose petal' appearance on diascopy?
question_description: Identify the skin condition characterized by 'dew drops on a rose petal' appearance on diascopy.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Vitiligo
options.description: Vitiligo presents with 'dew drops on a rose petal' appearance on diascopy, which is due to depigmented macules with underlying normal capillaries.

options.name: Pityriasis versicolor
options.description: Pityriasis versicolor typically shows fine, scaly, hypo- or hyperpigmented macules on diascopy, but not 'dew drops on a rose petal' appearance.

options.name: Tinea corporis
options.description: Tinea corporis presents with erythematous annular lesions with central clearing on diascopy, not 'dew drops on a rose petal' appearance.

options.name: Lichen planus
options.description: Lichen planus may show Wickham's striae under diascopy, but not specifically 'dew drops on a rose petal' appearance.

question_name: Which skin disorder is associated with anti-desmoglein antibodies?
question_description: Identify the skin disorder associated with antibodies against desmogleins.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Pemphigus vulgaris
options.description: Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by antibodies against desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3.

options.name: Bullous pemphigoid
options.description: Bullous pemphigoid is associated with antibodies against BP180 and BP230 antigens.

options.name: Dermatitis herpetiformis
options.description: Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with antibodies against epidermal transglutaminase.

options.name: Linear IgA dermatosis
options.description: Linear IgA dermatosis is associated with antibodies against basement membrane zone antigens.

question_name: Which condition is characterized by small, white papules on the buccal mucosa, along with reticulated white lines?
question_description: Identify the condition characterized by white papules on the buccal mucosa and reticulated white lines.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Lichen planus
options.description: Oral lichen planus presents with white papules on the buccal mucosa and reticulated white lines (Wickham's striae).

options.name: Oral leukoplakia
options.description: Oral leukoplakia presents as white patches or plaques on the oral mucosa but does not typically have reticulated lines.

options.name: Oral candidiasis
options.description: Oral candidiasis presents with white, curd-like patches that can be wiped off, not reticulated white lines.

options.name: Erythema multiforme
options.description: Erythema multiforme presents with targetoid lesions on the skin and mucous membranes, not white papules and lines.

question_name: Which vasculitis primarily affects medium-sized vessels and is associated with livedo reticularis?
question_description: Identify the vasculitis primarily affecting medium-sized vessels and associated with livedo reticularis.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Polyarteritis nodosa
options.description: Polyarteritis nodosa primarily affects medium-sized arteries and is associated with livedo reticularis.

options.name: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
options.description: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's) affects small vessels and is associated with granulomatous inflammation.

options.name: Microscopic polyangiitis
options.description: Microscopic polyangiitis affects small vessels and is associated with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

options.name: Kawasaki disease
options.description: Kawasaki disease primarily affects medium-sized arteries and is associated with mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

question_name: Which cutaneous feature is characteristic of dermatomyositis?
question_description: Identify the characteristic cutaneous feature of dermatomyositis.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Gottron's papules
options.description: Gottron's papules are characteristic papules overlying the joints, especially the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints, in dermatomyositis.

options.name: Heliotrope rash
options.description: Heliotrope rash is a violaceous rash on the eyelids in dermatomyositis.

options.name: Erythema multiforme
options.description: Erythema multiforme presents with targetoid lesions and is associated with infections and drug reactions.

options.name: Morphea
options.description: Morphea presents with localized scleroderma and typically lacks systemic involvement seen in dermatomyositis.

question_name: Which condition is associated with the presence of a 'deck-chair' sign on Wood's lamp examination?
question_description: Identify the condition associated with a 'deck-chair' sign under Wood's lamp.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Tinea versicolor
options.description: Tinea versicolor is characterized by hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules that fluoresce under Wood's lamp, producing a 'deck-chair' or 'bran-like' appearance.

options.name: Vitiligo
options.description: Vitiligo presents with depigmented macules that do not fluoresce under Wood's lamp.

options.name: Pityriasis rosea
options.description: Pityriasis rosea presents with a herald patch and does not typically fluoresce under Wood's lamp.

options.name: Erythrasma
options.description: Erythrasma is characterized by coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp due to porphyrins produced by Corynebacterium minutissimum.

subject: Microbiology

subject: Microbiology

subject: Microbiology

question_name: Which protozoan is responsible for causing African sleeping sickness?
subject: Microbiology

subject: Microbiology

question_name: Which fungus is responsible for causing histoplasmosis?
subject: Microbiology

question_name: Which virus is responsible for causing German measles?
subject: Microbiology

question_name: Which bacterium is responsible for causing Legionnaires' disease?
subject: Microbiology

question_name: Which virus is responsible for causing infectious mononucleosis, commonly known as mono?
subject: Microbiology

question_name: Which bacterium is known for causing whooping cough?
subject: Microbiology

question_name: Which virus is responsible for causing severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)?
subject: Microbiology

question_name: Which bacterium is primarily responsible for causing gas gangrene?

question_name: What is the normal range of body temperature in Celsius?
subject: Medicine

options.name: 36.1 to 37.2
options.description: The normal body temperature range is typically between 36.1 and 37.2 degrees Celsius.

options.name: 35.0 to 36.0
options.description: This range is generally considered below normal.

options.name: 37.5 to 38.5
options.description: This range is typically considered above normal.

options.name: 38.0 to 39.0
options.description: This range indicates a fever.

question_name: Which vitamin is known as ascorbic acid?

options.name: Vitamin A
options.description: Vitamin A is also known as retinol.

options.name: Vitamin B12
options.description: Vitamin B12 is also known as cobalamin.

options.name: Vitamin C
options.description: Vitamin C is also known as ascorbic acid.

options.name: Vitamin D
options.description: Vitamin D is also known as calciferol.

question_name: What is the common term for myocardial infarction?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Stroke
options.description: A stroke is a cerebrovascular accident.

options.name: Heart attack
options.description: Myocardial infarction is commonly known as a heart attack.

options.name: Angina
options.description: Angina is chest pain due to reduced blood flow to the heart.

options.name: Arrhythmia
options.description: Arrhythmia is an irregular heartbeat.

question_name: Which organ is primarily affected by hepatitis?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Heart
options.description: The heart is not primarily affected by hepatitis.

options.name: Kidneys
options.description: The kidneys are not primarily affected by hepatitis.

options.name: Liver
options.description: Hepatitis primarily affects the liver.

options.name: Lungs
options.description: The lungs are not primarily affected by hepatitis.

question_name: What is the primary function of red blood cells?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Fight infections
options.description: White blood cells fight infections.

options.name: Transport oxygen
options.description: Red blood cells transport oxygen to the body's tissues.

options.name: Clot blood
options.description: Platelets are responsible for blood clotting.

options.name: Produce hormones
options.description: Endocrine glands produce hormones.

question_name: Which disease is caused by a deficiency of insulin?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Diabetes mellitus
options.description: Diabetes mellitus is caused by a deficiency of insulin.

options.name: Hypothyroidism
options.description: Hypothyroidism is caused by a deficiency of thyroid hormones.

options.name: Addison's disease
options.description: Addison's disease is caused by a deficiency of adrenal hormones.

options.name: Cushing's syndrome
options.description: Cushing's syndrome is caused by excess cortisol.

question_name: What is the normal adult blood pressure range?
subject: Medicine

options.name: 120/80 mmHg
options.description: The normal blood pressure range for adults is around 120/80 mmHg.

options.name: 140/90 mmHg
options.description: This range is considered high blood pressure.

options.name: 100/70 mmHg
options.description: This is on the lower end but still within normal limits.

options.name: 160/100 mmHg
options.description: This range indicates hypertension.

question_name: Which condition is characterized by the inflammation of the joints?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Arthritis
options.description: Arthritis is characterized by the inflammation of the joints.

options.name: Osteoporosis
options.description: Osteoporosis is characterized by weak and brittle bones.

options.name: Fibromyalgia
options.description: Fibromyalgia is characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain.

options.name: Gout
options.description: Gout is a form of arthritis caused by excess uric acid.

question_name: Which organ is responsible for filtering blood and producing urine?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Heart
options.description: The heart pumps blood throughout the body.

options.name: Lungs
options.description: The lungs are responsible for gas exchange.

options.name: Kidneys
options.description: The kidneys filter blood and produce urine.

options.name: Liver
options.description: The liver detoxifies blood and produces bile.

question_name: Which type of blood cell is primarily involved in immune responses?

options.name: Red blood cells
options.description: Red blood cells transport oxygen.

options.name: Platelets
options.description: Platelets are involved in blood clotting.

options.name: White blood cells
options.description: White blood cells are primarily involved in immune responses.

options.name: Plasma cells
options.description: Plasma cells produce antibodies.

question_name: Which condition is characterized by high levels of cortisol?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Addison's disease
options.description: Addison's disease is characterized by low levels of cortisol.

options.name: Cushing's syndrome
options.description: Cushing's syndrome is characterized by high levels of cortisol.

options.name: Graves' disease
options.description: Graves' disease is characterized by high levels of thyroid hormones.

options.name: Hashimoto's thyroiditis
options.description: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by hypothyroidism.

question_name: Which heart valve is most commonly affected in rheumatic heart disease?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Aortic valve
options.description: The aortic valve is less commonly affected in rheumatic heart disease.

options.name: Mitral valve
options.description: The mitral valve is most commonly affected in rheumatic heart disease.

options.name: Pulmonary valve
options.description: The pulmonary valve is rarely affected in rheumatic heart disease.

options.name: Tricuspid valve
options.description: The tricuspid valve is less commonly affected in rheumatic heart disease.

question_name: What is the primary cause of chronic bronchitis?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Allergic reactions
options.description: Allergic reactions are not the primary cause of chronic bronchitis.

options.name: Smoking
options.description: Smoking is the primary cause of chronic bronchitis.

options.name: Viral infections
options.description: Viral infections can cause acute bronchitis, not chronic bronchitis.

options.name: Bacterial infections
options.description: Bacterial infections are less commonly the primary cause of chronic bronchitis.

question_name: Which condition is diagnosed using the Mantoux test?
subject: Medicine

options.description: The Mantoux test is used to diagnose tuberculosis.

options.name: HIV/AIDS
options.description: The Mantoux test is not used to diagnose HIV/AIDS.

options.name: Malaria
options.description: The Mantoux test is not used to diagnose malaria.

options.name: Hepatitis
options.description: The Mantoux test is not used to diagnose hepatitis.

question_name: Which electrolyte imbalance is most commonly seen in Addison's disease?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Hyperkalemia
options.description: Hyperkalemia is commonly seen in Addison's disease due to decreased aldosterone.

options.name: Hypokalemia
options.description: Hypokalemia is not commonly seen in Addison's disease.

options.name: Hypernatremia
options.description: Hypernatremia is not commonly seen in Addison's disease.

options.name: Hyponatremia
options.description: Hyponatremia is seen in Addison's disease but less commonly than hyperkalemia.

question_name: Which condition is characterized by episodic chest pain due to coronary artery spasm?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Stable angina
options.description: Stable angina is caused by fixed coronary artery stenosis.

options.name: Unstable angina
options.description: Unstable angina is caused by ruptured atherosclerotic plaque and thrombosis.

options.name: Prinzmetal's angina
options.description: Prinzmetal's angina is characterized by coronary artery spasm.

options.name: Myocardial infarction
options.description: Myocardial infarction is caused by prolonged ischemia leading to heart muscle death.

question_name: Which hormone is primarily responsible for regulating blood calcium levels?

options.name: Thyroxine

options.name: Parathyroid hormone
options.description: Parathyroid hormone primarily regulates blood calcium levels.

options.name: Cortisol
options.description: Cortisol regulates stress response and metabolism.

question_name: Which medication is commonly used as a first-line treatment for hypertension?

options.name: Diuretics

options.name: Beta-blockers

options.name: ACE inhibitors

options.name: Calcium channel blockers

options.name: Vitamin D

question_name: Which genetic disorder is characterized by the deletion of the long arm of chromosome 22?

options.name: Turner syndrome

options.name: DiGeorge syndrome

options.name: Klinefelter syndrome
options.description: Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by an extra X chromosome in males.

question_name: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by IgE antibodies?

options.name: Type II hypersensitivity

options.name: Type III hypersensitivity

options.name: Type IV hypersensitivity
options.description: Type IV hypersensitivity is mediated by T cells.

question_name: Which type of lung cancer is most strongly associated with smoking?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Adenocarcinoma

options.name: Small cell lung cancer
options.description: Small cell lung cancer is most strongly associated with smoking.

options.name: Squamous cell carcinoma
options.description: Squamous cell carcinoma is associated with smoking but not as strongly as small cell lung cancer.

options.name: Large cell carcinoma
options.description: Large cell carcinoma has a moderate association with smoking.

options.name: Crohn's disease

options.name: Celiac disease

question_name: Which cardiac marker is most specific for myocardial infarction?
subject: Medicine

options.name: CK-MB
options.description: CK-MB is sensitive but less specific than troponin for myocardial infarction.

options.name: Myoglobin
options.description: Myoglobin rises early but is not specific for myocardial infarction.

options.name: Troponin
options.description: Troponin is the most specific marker for myocardial infarction.

options.name: LDH
options.description: LDH is less specific and rises later than troponin.

options.description: Staphylococcus aureus is not typically associated with peptic ulcer disease.

options.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus

options.name: Rheumatoid arthritis

options.description: Hypernatremia is less commonly associated with diabetic ketoacidosis.

options.name: Hypokalemia

question_name: Which disorder is characterized by the progressive loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Alzheimer's disease
options.description: Alzheimer's disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid plaques and tau tangles.

options.name: Parkinson's disease
options.description: Parkinson's disease is characterized by the progressive loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra.

options.name: Multiple sclerosis
options.description: Multiple sclerosis is characterized by demyelination of neurons.

options.name: Huntington's disease
options.description: Huntington's disease is characterized by the accumulation of abnormal huntingtin protein.

question_name: Which pathogen is most commonly associated with infectious mononucleosis?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Cytomegalovirus

options.name: Epstein-Barr virus
options.description: Epstein-Barr virus is most commonly associated with infectious mononucleosis.

options.name: Herpes simplex virus
options.description: Herpes simplex virus is not commonly associated with infectious mononucleosis.

options.name: Human papillomavirus
options.description: Human papillomavirus is not associated with infectious mononucleosis.

question_name: Which neurological disorder is characterized by rapid progressive dementia, myoclonus, and periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
options.description: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is characterized by rapid progressive dementia, myoclonus, and periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG.

options.name: Alzheimer's disease
options.description: Alzheimer's disease is characterized by progressive memory loss and cognitive decline.

options.name: Huntington's disease
options.description: Huntington's disease is characterized by progressive motor dysfunction and cognitive decline.

options.name: Parkinson's disease
options.description: Parkinson's disease is characterized by motor symptoms such as tremor and rigidity.

question_name: Which autoimmune disorder primarily affects the peripheral nervous system with ascending muscle weakness?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Myasthenia gravis
options.description: Myasthenia gravis affects neuromuscular junctions but does not typically cause ascending muscle weakness.

options.name: Guillain-Barré syndrome
options.description: Guillain-Barré syndrome primarily affects the peripheral nervous system with ascending muscle weakness.

options.name: Multiple sclerosis
options.description: Multiple sclerosis affects the central nervous system with demyelination of neurons.

options.name: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
options.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis affects motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.

question_name: Which type of cardiomyopathy is characterized by ventricular hypertrophy without dilation?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Dilated cardiomyopathy
options.description: Dilated cardiomyopathy is characterized by ventricular dilation.

options.name: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
options.description: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by ventricular hypertrophy without dilation.

options.name: Restrictive cardiomyopathy
options.description: Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by impaired ventricular filling.

options.name: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy
options.description: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy is characterized by fibrofatty replacement of myocardium.

question_name: Which syndrome is characterized by the triad of hypothyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, and ovarian failure?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Turner syndrome
options.description: Turner syndrome involves ovarian failure but not hypothyroidism or adrenal insufficiency.

options.name: Cushing's syndrome
options.description: Cushing's syndrome involves adrenal hyperfunction, not adrenal insufficiency.

options.name: Polyglandular autoimmune syndrome type II
options.description: Polyglandular autoimmune syndrome type II is characterized by the triad of hypothyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, and ovarian failure.

options.name: Klinefelter syndrome
options.description: Klinefelter syndrome involves testicular failure, not ovarian failure.

question_name: Which type of renal stone is most likely to form in patients with chronic metabolic acidosis?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Calcium oxalate
options.description: Calcium oxalate stones are associated with hypercalciuria and hyperoxaluria.

options.name: Uric acid
options.description: Uric acid stones are more likely to form in patients with chronic metabolic acidosis.

options.name: Struvite
options.description: Struvite stones are associated with urinary tract infections.

options.name: Cystine
options.description: Cystine stones are associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder.

question_name: Which infectious disease is characterized by a biphasic fever pattern and a rash that begins on the wrists and ankles?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Typhoid fever
options.description: Typhoid fever has a prolonged fever and a different rash pattern.

options.name: Rocky Mountain spotted fever
options.description: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is characterized by a biphasic fever pattern and a rash that begins on the wrists and ankles.

options.name: Dengue fever
options.description: Dengue fever has a different rash pattern and fever course.

options.name: Measles
options.description: Measles has a distinct rash pattern and fever course.

question_name: Which vasculitis is most commonly associated with hepatitis B virus infection?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Giant cell arteritis
options.description: Giant cell arteritis is not associated with hepatitis B virus infection.

options.name: Polyarteritis nodosa
options.description: Polyarteritis nodosa is most commonly associated with hepatitis B virus infection.

options.name: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
options.description: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's) is associated with ANCA antibodies.

options.name: Kawasaki disease
options.description: Kawasaki disease primarily affects children and has an unknown etiology.

question_name: Which endocrine disorder is characterized by hypersecretion of cortisol from an adrenal adenoma?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Cushing's disease
options.description: Cushing's disease involves hypersecretion of ACTH from the pituitary gland.

options.name: Pheochromocytoma
options.description: Pheochromocytoma involves hypersecretion of catecholamines from the adrenal medulla.

options.name: Adrenal hyperplasia
options.description: Adrenal hyperplasia involves bilateral hyperplasia of the adrenal glands.

options.name: Adrenal adenoma
options.description: Adrenal adenoma causes hypersecretion of cortisol, leading to Cushing's syndrome.

question_name: Which type of shock is characterized by high cardiac output and low systemic vascular resistance?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Hypovolemic shock
options.description: Hypovolemic shock is characterized by low cardiac output and high systemic vascular resistance.

options.name: Cardiogenic shock
options.description: Cardiogenic shock is characterized by low cardiac output and high systemic vascular resistance.

options.name: Distributive shock
options.description: Distributive shock (e.g., septic shock) is characterized by high cardiac output and low systemic vascular resistance.

options.name: Obstructive shock
options.description: Obstructive shock is characterized by mechanical obstruction to blood flow.

question_name: Which malignancy is most commonly associated with a paraneoplastic syndrome involving Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome?
subject: Medicine

options.name: Small cell lung cancer
options.description: Small cell lung cancer is most commonly associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) as a paraneoplastic syndrome.

options.name: Non-small cell lung cancer
options.description: Non-small cell lung cancer is less commonly associated with LEMS.

options.name: Breast cancer
options.description: Breast cancer is not typically associated with LEMS.

options.name: Pancreatic cancer
options.description: Pancreatic cancer can have various paraneoplastic syndromes, but not commonly LEMS.
